Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The multi-scale physics of massive black hole formation, fueling and feedback
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will create a Theoretical and Computational Astrophysics Network with major nodes at the University of Maryland, the Georgia Institute of Technology, and Yale University to advance the theory of formation, fueling, and feedback of supermassive black holes (SMBHs). The project proposes to accomplish this task by linking computational codes simulating large-scale SMBH phenomena (i.e. cosmological gravitational collapse and AGN jets) to the small-scale phenomena (i.e. SMBH formation and feedback on galactic structure). For the "formation stage", the project intends to answer the question of how the first black hole (BH) seeds formed within the early universe by numerically simulating the coupling of large-scale baryonic structures and dark-matter halos to small-scale collapse of primordial gas disks into massive BH seeds. For the "fueling stage" the project aims to explore the growth of the BH seed into a SMBH from galaxy-scale accretion flows to SMBH mergers. Finally, for the "feedback stage" the goal is to explore the mechanisms by which the SMBHs at the centers of active galactic nuclei (AGN) couple to the inter-cluster plasma on cosmological scales. The network will contribute to scientific workforce development through the involvement of undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs. The project will communicate results to the public through development of a 3-D visualization taking the viewer on a journey to witness the birth and growth of a SMBH and its influence on the cosmological environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Some of the most important questions in contemporary astrophysics pertain to the formation and growth of the most massive black holes in the universe, as well as the impact that they have on their environment. The goal of this Theoretical and Computational Astrophysics Network (TCAN) is to provide a coherent view of the life of a supermassive black hole, from the creation of the first seed to the role that they play in today’s galaxies.  While this picture remains to be completed, we have made several important steps that contribute to understanding of these processes. We highlight several results related to the formation, fueling and feedback from supermassive black holes that have emerged thanks to the support from this project:

- Formation: Georgia Tech TCAN members and their collaborators have investigated conditions under which black holes can form as a consequence of direct collapse of gas in the early universe. It has been shown that this is possible as long as the region of direct collapse is irradiated by the energetic UV and X-ray radiation from an adjacent galaxy, located not more than 3000 light years away. Related work by our TCAN members also shows that massive black hole seeds in stellar bulges remain viable channel for formation of supermassive black holes even in presence of radiative feedback. 

- Fueling: We have investigated the structure of nuclear starburst disks and found that they can effectively obscure central regions of their host galaxies. This scenario preferentially plays out in galaxies at intermediate redshift that contain abundant amounts of gas. The same galaxies tend to have actively accreting central black holes, therefore pointing to nuclear star-formation as a means to both fuel and obscure active galactic nuclei.  

- Feedback: We have also investigated the efficiency of dynamical friction in presence of black hole radiative feedback. Dynamical friction is thought to be a principal mechanism responsible for orbital evolution of supermassive black holes in the aftermath of galactic mergers. We find that ionizing radiation that emerges from the innermost parts of the black holes accretion flow renders dynamical friction inefficient for a range of physical scenarios. Our results suggest that suppression of dynamical friction is more severe at the lower mass end of the supermassive black hole spectrum and that black holes with mass below ten million solar masses have fewer means to reach the centers of merged galaxies. 

These results have been obtained by theoretical modeling of multi-scale physics and high performance computing. The scientific team that has contributed to this TCAN project at Georgia Tech includes three faculty, two postdoctoral researchers, six graduate students and four undergraduate researchers. Their work resulted in 20 scientific publications, two doctoral theses, a number of professional and public talks, several outreach events, and one project website.
